text: on Thursday Admiral Mike Mullen the
chairman the Joint Chiefs of Staff met
with his Pakistani military counterparts
for the second time in two weeks to
discuss the urgent situation in the Swat
lunare area the Pakistani army is
trained to fight a conventional war
against India not a counter insurgency
against the Taliban or that its allies
and so they've come up short in several
instances and it's only been in the last
year where they've even started to
incorporate some of the
counterinsurgency tactics that the US
for instance used effectively in Iraq
and as using trying to use in
Afghanistan now the United States is in
a difficult position right now it
doesn't have a whole lot of leverage
over Pakistan the civilian government is
weak somewhat fractured right now the
military was reluctant to launch a major
counter-offensive against the militancy
without some political cover for their
civilian leadership and in addition to
that the military has already spread
thin through many of the tribal regions
the Americans of course and the tribal
areas have been using the Predator
drones to go after al-qaeda and other
senior militants problem is you can't
use these type of drones in this more
much more interior part of Pakistan it's
part of Pakistan proper if you will so
this is really much more of a Pakistani
security problem and it's coming upon
American officials to try and prod the
Pakistanis to do more the immediate goal
is to stem the militancy the militancy
is still some 60 or 70 miles away from
the Pakistani capital this is not a
straight shot by any means there are
mountain ranges in between this region
and the capital this region's some
northwest of Islamabad so I think the
immediate issue for the Pakistani
security forces is to contain the
spreading militancy which is now
threatening to spill over into some of
these other adjoining districts before
it reaches deeper into the heart of
Punjab province and the real heartland
of Pakistan
you
